case_vignette: A 26-year-old man presents to the behavioral health clinic for assistance overcoming his fear of public speaking. He has always hated public speaking. Two weeks ago, he was supposed to present a research project at school but had to leave the podium before the presentation. He recalled that his heart was racing, his palms were sweating, and that he could not breathe. These symptoms resolved on their own after several minutes, but he felt too embarrassed to return to college the next day. This had also happened in high school where, before a presentation, he started sweating and felt palpitations and nausea that also resolved on their own. He is scheduled for another presentation next month and is terrified. He states that this only happens in front of large groups and that he has no problems communicating at small gatherings. Other than his fear of public speaking, he has a normal social life and many friends. He enjoys his classes and a part-time job.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I get really nervous, my heart starts beating fast, my hands get sweaty, and I feel like I can't breathe when I have to speak in front of a lot of people.
Is this a recurring issue during public speaking engagements?
Yes, it happened in high school and two weeks ago before a presentation at school.
Do you have any known family history of anxiety disorders?
I don't know, I'm just a patient talking about my own symptoms.
Have you ever been diagnosed with or treated for anxiety before?
No, I haven't been diagnosed or treated for anxiety before.
Based on your symptoms, I would diagnose you with Social Anxiety Disorder.

The patient's female partner was diagnosed with chlamydia last year, but the patient has not been checked for it. The patient is does not have any other medical conditions and is not taking any medications. There's no family history of skin conditions or autoimmune diseases.
trial_0.vignette_mcq: The most likely diagnosis is Social anxiety disorder. The patient's symptoms of fear, racing heart, sweating, and shortness of breath specifically in relation to public speaking and large groups are consistent with this diagnosis. Panic disorder may also include these symptoms, but it is characterized by unexpected and recurrent panic attacks, not just in response to a specific situation or fear. Panic disorder with agoraphobia involves fear of public places and may include avoidance behaviors beyond just public speaking. Normal human behavior does not involve the level of fear and avoidance described in this case. Performance only anxiety is a type of social anxiety disorder where the fear is specifically related to performing in front of others.
